references: FedElasticNet is a general framework; hence, it can be integrated with prior FL algorithms such as FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b), SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021) so as to resolve the client drift problem as well as the communication cost problem. Further, it incurs no additional costs in training. Empirically, we show that FedElasticNet enhances communication efficiency while maintaining the classification accuracy even for heterogeneous datasets, i.e., the client drift problem is resolved. Theoretically, we characterize the impact of the regularizer terms. TableÂ 1 compares the prior methods and the proposed FedElasticNet if integrated with FedDyn (AlgorithmÂ 3).

references: TableÂ 2 reports the number of non-zero elements of the baseline methods with/without FedElasticNet. Basically, the communication costs per round of FedProx and FedDyn are the same; SCAFFOLD suffers from the doubled communication cost because of the control variates. The proposed FedElasticNet integrations (AlgorithmsÂ 1, Â 2, andÂ 3) can effectively sparsify the transmitted local updates, which enhances communication efficiency.

references: We compare the baseline methods (FedProx, SCAFFOLD, and FedDyn) and the proposed FedElasticNet integrations (AlgorithmsÂ

), respectively. We evaluate the communication cost and classification accuracy for non-IID settings of the prior methods and the proposed methods. The robustness of the client drift problem is measured by the classification accuracy of non-IID settings.
We report the communication costs in two ways: (i) the number of nonzero elements in transmitted values as in
and (ii) the Shannon entropy of transmitted bits. Note that the Shannon entropy is the theoretical limit of data compressionÂ
, which can be achieved by practical algorithms; for instance,

used Huffman coding for model compression. We calculate the entropy of discretized values with the bin size of 0.01. Note that the transmitted values are not discretized in FL, and only the discretization is considered to calculate the entropy. The lossy compression schemes (e.g., scalar quantization, vector quantization, etc.) have not been considered since they include several implementational issues which are beyond our research scope.

reports the number of non-zero elements of the baseline methods with/without FedElasticNet. Basically, the communication costs per round of FedProx and FedDyn are the same; SCAFFOLD suffers from the doubled communication cost because of the control variates. The proposed FedElasticNet integrations (AlgorithmsÂ
) can effectively sparsify the transmitted local updates, which enhances communication efficiency.
In particular, the minimal communication cost is achieved when FedElasticNet is integrated with FedDyn (AlgorithmÂ
). It is because the classification accuracy is not degraded even if the transmitted values are more aggressively sparsified in AlgorithmÂ
are sparser than FedDyn and AlgorithmÂ
(FedElasticNet for FedDyn) achieves the best communication efficiency.

report the Shannon entropy of transmitted bits for the baseline methods with/without FedElasticNet. The communication costs of baseline methods are effectively improved by the FedElasticNet approach. AlgorithmsÂ
reduce the entropy compared to the their baseline methods. We note that FedElasticNet integrated with FedDyn (AlgorithmÂ
) achieves the minimum entropy, i.e., the minimum communication cost.
For FedDyn, we evaluate the Shannon entropy values for two cases: (i) transmit the updated local models
. We observe that transmitting the local updates
can reduce the Shannon entropy significantly. Hence, it is beneficial to transmit the local updates
even for FedDyn if it adopts an additional compression scheme. The numbers of nonzero elements for two cases (i.e.,
shows that the FedElasticNet maintains the classification accuracy or incurs marginal degradation. We observe a classification gap between FedProx and AlgorithmÂ
for CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. However, the classification accuracies of FedDyn and AlgorithmÂ
are almost identical in the converged regime.
significantly reduces the Shannon entropy, which can be explained by FigÂ
compares the distributions of the transmitted local updates
-norm penalty on the local updates, AlgorithmÂ

makes sparser local updates than FedDyn. The local updates of FedDyn can be modeled by the Gaussian distribution, and the local updates of FedElasticNet can be modeled by the non-Gaussian distribution (similar to the Laplacian distribution). It is well-known that the Gaussian distribution maximizes the entropy for a given variance in information theoryÂ
. Hence, FedElasticNet can reduce the entropy by transforming the Gaussian distribution into the non-Gaussian one.
